data.name: #1 • A nugget problem
data.description:
**A nugget problem**  (Estimated Rank : 5 kyu)

***Introduction***

You are walking outside and you are hungry. Luckily, you see a fast food restaurant, and you already know what you're going to eat : *nuggets*.

Last time you went to this restaurant, you ordered too many nuggets. You couldn't eat them all :( . Now you know how many of them you will eat : 17.

Now comes the real problem : you can't buy a box of 17. In this restaurant, they sell boxes of 4, 6, 9, and 20. You *could* buy a box of 20, but it's too much for you. So you do some math and decide to buy two boxes of 4 and one of 9, because it sums up to 17. You can finally eat some yummy nuggets.

***Task***

You are given three arguments `box_one`, `box_two` and `nuggets_wanted` (you can change their names) for the function `nuggets`.

The problem is simplified. You only have two different boxes of nuggets. Your task is to return `True` if it is possible to obtain `nuggets_wanted` nuggets by buying boxes of `box_one` or `box_two` nuggets. Return `False` if you can't.

Suppose you can buy an infinite amount of boxes. `box_one` and `box_two` will always be different and strictly positive, and `nuggets_wanted` will always be strictly bigger than both `box_one` and `box_two` or equal to `0`.

***Examples***

```python
nuggets(3, 5, 23) # Should return True
nuggets(3, 4, 5) # Should return False
```

***Good luck and have fun ! This is my first kata, hope you enjoy it !***

Other problems of [Fun Problems](https://www.codewars.com/collections/5e8e10c835ad8c000f4e237b) :
